Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Polarimetric-Raman Lidar for Tropospheric Ice and Liquid Water Fractions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Raman spectroscopy probes the chemical and physical states of matter through inelastic scattering from the vibrational rotational and low frequency modes of molecular systems. In the atmosphere, one of the most abundant Raman scatterers is water, in its ice, liquid and vapour phases, and in their admixture. This EAGER award seeks to improve the feasibility of Raman spectroscopy combined with polarimetric Lidar (light detection and ranging) to remotely profile the fraction of water phases in tropospheric aerosols and cloud layers.

This proposal meets one or more of the EAGER criteria because the work is exploratory in nature and the particular approach, using a near IR Fourier Transform Spectrometer (FTS) theoretically capable of the requisite high spectral resolution, is largely untested in this configuration. The ability of the FTS to perform satisfactorily under high background light conditions (e.g. daylight or twilight) is likely to be a main element of proposal risk.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Annual Project Report (Period 05/01/2016 to 04/30/2017)

Project Advances

Advances in this period correspond to the final phase of the proposed instrument development.

In this period mechanical and opto –mechanical pieces needed to integrate and mount the lidar instrument have been fabricated. Similarly, in this period we layout and fine-tuned the spectrometric configuration. This was achieved by optically testing the lidar channel ports using a calibrated fiber-coupled laboratory spectrometer (iHR-550 Horiba Jobin Yvon).

The following tasks have been accomplished:

1-    Finished the mechanical design and implementation of the coupler piece between the receiver spectrometer and the telescope. This is a custom piece adapts the telescope to the optical breadboard. This piece was fabricated in high resistance plastic material using a 3D printing machine.

2-    Implemented the spectrometer closure rear and lateral and spectrometer topper. These are just walls to cover the spectrometer box but in their implementation light traps were included on the joints to reduce ambient straight light contaminating the receiver. Also we implemented walls to separate and optically isolate receiver channels. Separating walls are important to decrease as much as possible the cross talk between Raman channels caused by scattered light on optical interfaces.

3-    Designed and implemented a custom mechanical piece to hold the photomultiplier (PMT) detectors in place and attach it mechanically to the tri-axial motion platform. These are custom pieces to hold a bulky detector on a fixed position mechanically attached to the tri-axial platform for alignment and final positioning. The six pieces one per channel were made on 3D printing machine based on a lightweight and thermally stable material.

4-    Fabricated an opto-mechanic system to hold the polarized beam splitter (BS) in place while breadboard is placed horizontally or in final conditions standing vertically. The BS-polarizer is a 50 mm crystal cube with clear aperture large enough to clear the 1.75” diameter collimated beam coming from the telescope. For such crystal dimensions a mechanical holding piece was designed to cover the requirement of a vertical standing platform. No such piece exists in the market for that crystal dimension. The fabrication was done in 3D printing machine with matching holes to attach to the optical breadboard and also maximizing clear aperture on three crystal sides.

5-    Opto-mechanic receiver was disassembly from the laboratory configuration and was moved to the Lidar Laboratory on the roof of the Geophysical Institute for final position and atmospheric testing. There, is being re-assembled behind the telescope.

6-    Prepared the hardware to hold the telescope and laser emission. Telescope is already in position and ready for final assembly.

7-    Implemented the power units all cabled and assembled to power the photon counting unit and the discriminator’s board.

8-    Implemented detector’s power supply with independent voltage-gain control regulators. This voltage regulation is controlled by precision multi-turns potentiometer and each individual circuit feeds independently the six PMT detectors and have independent gain control for each channels depending upon the signal sensitivity.

Delays in covering the proposed milestones for this project: Optical testing in the laboratory was based on a broadband unpolarized light source. This microscope light source is wideband and stable enough to produce reliable measurements however the light is not polarized. This feature caused a lot of tedious and long laboratory hours to reach the right configuration in which the combination of dichroic mirrors and razor filter should work on each channel. The dichroic mirrors are based on thin films crystals that are polarization dependent and work only under one specific linear polarization state. This is good for a laser-based spectroscopy instrument since spontaneous Raman scattering signal follows the polarization of the laser stimulation (with the exception of asymmetric molecular bonds that produces depolarization). Therefore, we try to find the best combination of angle positioning on the dichroic and razors that we believe would work. Once this task was done and in order to move the project to a final phase we moved the spectrometer to the Lidar Laboratory to start mounting it together with the telescope and do a final fine-tuning over pre-fixed dichroic and razors filters positions.  

Project Outcomes 

“Lidar to Determine the Fractions of Ice, Liquid and Water Vapor in Polar Tropospheric Cloud”. Fochesatto G. J., O. Galvez, P. Ristori, D. Keller and E. L. Fochesatto. Accepted paper peer reviewed proceedings of the 28thInternational Laser Radar Conference, Bucharest, Romania. June 25-30, 2017.

"Unusually Deep Wintertime Cirrus Clouds Observed over the Alaskan Sub-Arctic" Authors: James R. Campbell, D. A. Peterson, J. W. Marquis, G. J. Fochesatto; M. A. Vaughan, S. A. Stewart and J. L. Tackett, S. Lolli; J. R. Lewis, M. I. Oyola, E. J. Welton. Submitted May 01, 2017to the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society.
